p: A primary goal in presenting this framework is to provide a pathway for eventually developing a robust predictive model for understanding the contributions of the health systems to climate-related instability that could be used for health policy interventions. One example application is the development of early warning systems; several already exist for aspects of the pathways we discuss. For instance, USAID developed the Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWS NET), that provides food insecurity risk assessments for 34 countries, using a combination of climate, economic, governance, and health data ( Brown and Brickley 2012). Using historical climate and disease incidence data, health researchers have developed early warning systems for infectious diseases such as malaria ( Thomson et al. 2005). The U.S. Department of Defense commissioned the Integrated Crisis Early Warning System (ICEWS) that uses news reports, social media data, and historical conflict information to predict future instability ( O’Brien 2010). However, to our knowledge, these systems have not been joined together or used to holistically predict social instability associated with climate change.
